title: Earring Completely 3-D Printed.
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This earring is completely 3-d printed.
A homage to the simple wooden earring, with a low poly modern touch.
You will love that little thing as much as I do! Have no 3D printer? Buy this earring at my store: http://birs73.ch/en

• Print at finest resolution. I used PLA.
  • Put in ear.
  • Be awesome

comments.text: How does it sit in your ear? I would imagine it being kind of uncomfortable since it's not a round stick that's inside the piercing. Have you tested out how long you can wear them before they get uncomfortable?
comments.author: ibjuliangrapes

comments.text: I did wear it for months. Your ear won't be able to tell if the stick is round or square.
comments.author: ibjuliangrapes

title: Monoprice Spool Mount for Mendel
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Simple mounting bracket to mount Monoprice spools onto the top-right or top-left part of your Mendel-style RepRap. Print 1 Spool Mount
Print 2 or more Connectors
Requires an M4 nut/screw for each connector Note: The holes might be a bit tight. You might need to drill through if the screw doesn't go through easily.

author: WWC

description.text: This thing has moved to Youmagine https://www.youmagine.com/users/jensa so I don't also get sued by Stratasys... Knob for three position switch

This knob fits a switch that move my electrical awning in/out. Hard to describe so it's searchable as there's no markings on the switch, but check out the images to see how it connects/sits inside the switch. It's sort of a special design and it should be easy to see if this knob will work for you as well.
Junior managed to hurt himself on the old and broken one that were in our house when we moved in, so I made a printable replacement in Glow-in-the-dark PLA from Faberdashery so now the knob is easy to find in the evening :)

description.text:
This is a very basic model of Sabine's blaster from Star Wars (The Clone Wars series). It's basic enough that it could be a Westar-35 as well.  
Latest update on 3/30/2014. More updates to come.  
Note: I haven't printed this yet, so I'm not sure what the printed version looks like.
Update 3/30/2014: "Basic" version is the updated version. As I'm printing it now, I've noticed that it didn't lay flat. Problem fixed.

comments.text: How long should this be? When I load up the file its super tiny
comments.author: James_v_v

comments.text: I may have modeled them in inches. Perhaps you may be looking in mm instead? I believe it's about 10" long.
comments.author: James_v_v

description.text:
Designed for the concept of making basic standard of living goods available to all. This thingi is a 100% Makerbotable Water Strainer designed for use with food produce.
Working within the build constraints of the makerbot this DIY stainer is aimed to house the maximum quantity of food product (rice, pasta, vegetables) while maintaining a nice water flow. This design has a rim surrounding the entire edge of the strainer for easy hold and also includes a secondary clip on handle for use with heated produce. ENJOY CLEAN EATING!

Print it.
Clip it together.
Both models available below and also in a compressed rar file.
ENJOY CLEAN EATING!

comments.text: A strainer is a great idea, and this looks like a good design, but... does it have enough holes?  It seems that it would overflow if you poured very fast at all.
comments.author: wurp

description.text:
It works!
Its more a test than useful, but its technically accurate. 3 layers thick at .3
Print without any perimiter if your printer doesn't join the edges so well, it will look better. Its 99% its intended size, the specification is 90mm, scaled down to account for printing wierdness.

comments.text: You could definitely put old film negatives in the holes and make a fun keepsake for your old photos!

remixed_from.author: MaximSachs
remixed_from.title: MaxGlide - Glidecam simple, efficient and cheap!

title: (almost) fully printed GoPro steady cam
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This steady cam only needs a few non-printed parts, the rest can be printed. Z rotation is enabled by a 608 ball bearing, while the other two axes are just running on M4 screws. The design works great - of course, a "pendulum type" steady cam like this one has some drawbacks, but it's still good enough for some really nice action footage! After designing this, I found one here which is also very simple and cheap and additionally has a very nice design: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:84142. Maybe I should have searched first ;-)
I really liked MaximFilm's idea of the handles for the threaded rod, so I decided to adopt it and also add one above and below the gimbal. Anyway, this one is even cheaper. I paid 1 Euro for a 1m M8 rod and about 3 Euros for almost a kilogram of nuts and washers at our local hardware discounter. The most expensive part is the bearing - if you have to buy it. I took mine from an old pair of rollerblades. So, together with approx. 20 meters of PLA, total cost is much less than 10 Euros. UPDATE: Parts were re-uploaded in the orientation I printed them.

You will need the STLs printed (all of them should print without support besides the GoPro mount) plus:
  • one 608 ball bearing
  • 9 M8 nuts
  • some M8 washers
  • an M8 threaded rod, length still tbd - I think it will be around 40 cm
  • an M8x100mm screw for the handle
  • four M4 x 20 mm screws (you will have to trim them)
  • four M4 self-locking nuts
  • four M4 washers
  • some big washers as a weight (I used 10 with a 13 mm bore, so I used the "Weight tube" printed part to center them)

comments.text: Where does the bearing go?
comments.author: sammyt152

comments.text: scratch that, i figured it out. However, how did you tighted the bolts so that the werent hitting the sides of the rotating pieces? Like how do you get the bolt head inside the plastic as well as the nut on the other side. (Yes I know we have to trim them)
comments.author: sammyt152

comments.text: Please can you tell me how you sliced these parts as I would like to make this thing. I have to assume that you re-orientated most of the parts compared to the published STLs and used support material as some of the parts, especially the GoPro mount look very tricky no matter what orientation you put them into Thank you, Alan
comments.author: Alzibiff

comments.text: Of course. The GoPro mount was printed as the STL is oriented with support (Cura: "Touching printbed"). The other parts were printed after rotating them by 90 degrees (gimbal flat on the bed, hande upside down and the two tubes standing) without support. I will upload some correctly oriented files in a few minutes, maybe this will be helpful.
comments.author: Alzibiff

comments.text:
Thank you HamOp - I rotated the original gimbal STL in advance of your recent uploads and printed it out earlier today. The rest should follow tomorrow. It looks as though I may get away with a set of 16mm M4 screws for the gimbal into nyloc nuts which will avoid any "trimming" but I have yet to confirm this.
Alan
comments.author: HamOp

comments.text:
Thanks for the feedback, Alan. Indeed, 16 mm screws should fit, however, when assembling mine, I found that I had to trim the length a little bit to allow a free movement of the gimbal - my nyloc nuts were so tight that I was afraid to fully tighten them as I didn't want to split the printed part by forcing the nut to rotate in its cavity.
Please keep me updated how the thing works for you.
comments.author: Alzibiff

comments.text:
I confirm I used M4x16mm for the gimbal. But Rather than using self locking nuts, I used a special glue (Loctite Blocpress 638). this avoid the issue when tightening.
My gimbal will be used for diving so the glue also protect against rust
comments.author: HamOp

comments.text: How would one go about preparing the PCB files for OSHPark? They accept "Gerber CAM files (in Zip format)" and Eagle files. The files here claim to be Gerber, and are in a zipfile, but OSH Park can't recognize them...
comments.author: ScooterScott

comments.text:
I was designed using the K2CAD. (Old shareware of Japan)
This Gerber is single-side and no regist-mask. Less than those that OSH Park requests.

title: Double 40mm Fan support for MendelMax 1.5 and 2.0

description.text:
I designed this small support to hold a couple of 40mm fan, the plate is made to fit aluminum profiles of a mendelmax 1.5!
I'm using it as part of the cooling system of the electronics. UPDATE: User @Ubermeisters try it on his Mendel max 2.0 and it works!!

Print it without support, I printed my out of PLA 3mm with a 0.5nozzle.
0.3mm layers/0.2 infill/ 2 top-bottom / 2 wall.
It takes 20 min to print at 100mm/min. It's design to fit M3x12 socket screw to hold the fan, and M5x10 socket screw to be fixed to the aluminum profiles with a couple of t-slot nut. thank you!

comments.text: hello! thank you! in this version the distance it's 53mm!! thank you!
comments.author: AndreaSignoretto

comments.text: Looks like it may also fit the MM2? distance between 20mm extrusions on mine is ~30mm
comments.author: Ubermeisters

comments.text: hello! thank you! in this version the distance it's 53mm!! Sorry, I'm wrong, 53mm is the distance between the axis of the holes, so it could be fitting properly on the MM2. In case let me know!! Thank you @ubermeisters
comments.author: Ubermeisters

comments.text: yes, i get 53mm from center of the channels in the extrusions. you can update to say it fits the MM2 !!
comments.author: AndreaSignoretto

comments.text: Thank You Very Much for the information!!
comments.author: Ubermeisters
